author: .paulharris
content: i guess ssv has a vested interest in diversity of the fleet also, but worth considering if we're having the discussion

author: celtic.warrior
content: SSV doesn't really promote maximal client diversity in an organized way.  Although it is an obvious benefit of the tech, particularly now that v2.3.8 requires 3/4 agreement among the nodes for an attestation to be signed by a validator.  That recent client update could be used to significantly harden the network against a majority client bug.  Maybe something for EthResearch to discuss with them.

author: greystroke
content:
Any thoughts on updating maxeb such that the max capacity of 0x02 validators has more options?  I believe there are many stakers who would consolidate to help decrease network load but want the liquidity of 0x01 validators.  If MaxEB provided choices like 128, 256, 512, 1024, 2048, 4096 & 8192 ETH for 0x02 validators,  i believe there would be more net consolidation. 

This is a more reasonable & practical solution than the reactionary EIP 8062 that penalizes non-whale 0x01 validators if they do not switch to 0x02 validators with a max 2048 ETH cap.

author: .paulharris
content: it was an option when we did maxEB but its non trivial, so we went with a single max. It'd be an entire EIP to do it, its pretty invasive because effective balance is used pretty heavily. the original maxEB design used the blank space of withdrawal credentials to store what the individual validator desired for their max effective balance iirc.

author: greystroke
content: I guess it all depends on how urgently we want to see consolidation of the validator set. I do think though this is a better solution than one that penalizes non-whale solo stakers like eip-8062 if Ethereum values the role of solo stakers in the network.

author: .paulharris
content: im not sold that 8062 solves anything, even 0'd validators in the set is not great, so having ppl have to pay for withdrawals doesnt improve anything imo

author: celtic.warrior
content: It's not just solo stakers that get penalized.  Pro and institutional stakers also get penalized if they need predictable cashflow from their validators and cannot consolidate to 2048 ETH validators due to risk concerns.  EIP 8062 is an example of an EIP attempts to apply the wrong fix to the wrong problem.

author: greystroke
content: By 0'd validators,  are you referring to withdrawn/slashed ones? If so,  what the issue with them?

author: .paulharris
content: 0 balance validators - they're over half the validator array and by spec we iterate that entire array several times each epoch transition. That's expensive, and the size/fragmentation of that array is a big driver for why the deposit queue (actually processing rate) is what it is.

author: greystroke
content: Would it be feasible to resolve with an EIP where newly deposited validators are able to reuse the index # of fully exited validators?

author: .paulharris
content: there was one at one point to reuse iirc - we need a solution, not sure what the best one is... obviously its nice to not have huge changes in that list, but we also can't grow state forever, so maybe either reuse, or changing the structure to an active validators vector or there'll be other potential solutions... but something has to happen there at some point
